intro: Lepidium arvense, commonly known as field peppergrass, is an annual flowering plant native to temperate regions of the Northern Hemisphere. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes many economically important crops such as cabbage and mustard. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 centimeters, with small, yellow flowers that bloom in early summer. Its leaves are alternate, pinnately divided, and covered with fine, branched hairs. The fruit is a small, dry capsule containing several seeds, which are dispersed by wind.
